text:
It is an honor to
be here with you.

And I am what I call a fake
academic because I've only
been teaching for five years.

And no one is more astonished
than me that I have tenure.

I mean, it's just like crazy
to be in my position right now.

But before I started
teaching, I did

a lot of human rights and
social justice activism.

So I'm what they call
a clinical professor.

I teach in the classroom what
I learned in the community,
basically.

And my course right now
is called White Supremacy
in the Age of Trump.

So you can tell I'm having a
ball, because a lot of people

experience fascism, and a few
of us get paid to fight it.

And that is a very
privileged position to be in.

And so it is my joy to
teach young people that this
is their lunch counter moment.

Maybe they don't
know what they would

have done in the '50s when
they got spit upon and punched

and all of that, but you
don't have to go back there.

This is our lunch counter
moment, our chance

to stand up against fascism,
our chance to defend democracy,
our chance to defend truth.

And so let me talk
about my presentation

because they're going
to probably pull a hook

and pull me off stage if I
don't hurry up and get to it.

I believe that the people who
are opposed to human rights

mistakenly think that they're
fighting us, the human rights
movement.

But I actually
think they're wrong.
We're fighting them.

We're not mistaken
about who our target is.

But I think they're
wrong because I

think what they're doing is that
they're trying to fight truth.

They're trying to
fight evidence.

They're trying to fight
history, with the attacks on CRT
and all of that.

But most of all, they're
trying to fight time,

as if a bunch of angry,
aggrieved white men

could just roll us back to the
19th century on their say-so.

They are so overmatched,
they don't even know it.

And by the way,
they're demographically

doomed because their
whole plan hinges

on convincing a lot of
white women to have 18 kids
and counting.

And I don't think
that's going to happen.

I don't care what
restrictions you

put on birth control and
abortion and sex education.

You will not be able to
manipulate enough white women

to make The Handmaid's
Tale come true.

So there is their
demographic doom.

But with truth,
time, and evidence

and history on our
side, my biggest fear

is that we will snatch defeat
from the jaws of victory

with our callout culture because
we're spending entirely too

much time turning on each
other instead of to each other

in face of the greatest threat
we have seen in our lifetimes.

And so I went from working on
issues like abortion and human

rights and white supremacy
and violence against women--

those are my issues
that I work on--

to focus on our process,
because how we do the work

is as important as
the work that we do.

How you choose to
struggle for human rights

is a statement of your
values, what kind of world
you would build if you won.

And it's truly a
master's tools thing.

Because you just quoted
Audrey, of course

I've got to bring
Audrey in here.

We cannot use the tactics of
the prison industrial complex--

the exiling, the punishment,
the shaming, and the silencing--

and deconstruct
the master's house.

Matter of fact, those tools
don't even work for the master.

Have y'all ever
heard of recidivism?

So why in the
world we think they
would work for us is beyond me.

And I believe that learning
calling in techniques

in the 21st century will be
a statement of our values,

just like learning nonviolent
techniques in the 20th century

bespoke the values of the
Civil Rights movement.

A statement of how we
value the struggle,

how we value ourselves,
and how we refuse

to dehumanize our opponents
even as they dehumanize us,

because we have to prove
both within our hearts

and in our practices
that we will not

sink to the level of our
opponents, because when we do,
we've already lost.

So let's talk about
the callout culture.

And somebody hopefully
does a time check for me,
because I can talk.
She definitely would do it.
I know from experience.
OK.

When I started analyzing
the calling out culture,

I was actually
astonished because I

knew people were
daring to say things

online to each other they didn't
dare say to each other's faces.

And when I started asking
young people about it who

are immersed in the
social media world,

I found that they were
censoring themselves

for fear of saying
the wrong thing,

for having some tweet
unearthed 20 years later

that could cost them a
college entrance or a job
or something like that.

So it was really having
a terrible impact
on young people.

And so I started trying to
analyze what was going on,

not because I'm unfamiliar
with the callout culture--

I mean, back in the
'70s, when I started

in the women's movement,
we called it trashing.

So it ain't like we're
unfamiliar with the practice.

And actually, the original
definition of calling out
was inviting people to a duel.

I mean, that's how Alexander
Hamilton got killed,
if you might recall.

So it ain't like this behavior
was created with social media.

It just gets amplified and
viralized through social media.

But people have been
doing it all along.

So when I started
analyzing it, i

created something called
the Five C Continuum.

And it's composed of calling
out, canceling, calling in,
calling on, and calling it off.

And I'll be talking
about those each.

Calling out, we all know what
it is because it's publicly

shaming people for things
you think they've done wrong.

And you want to hold
them accountable,

but you're choosing to publicly
shame them by doing so.

And the word that's working
most in that sentence

is you're doing it publicly,
because obviously you

could privately pull them
aside and say, you know,

when you use that word, we
don't use that word anymore,

or when you misgendered
that person,

maybe you could walk
up to them and ask them
what their gender pronouns are.

Instead we'll say,
"I can't believe you
did that," kind of approach.

And the minute you have
that kind of public shaming

response, you've invited
them into a fight, not

a conversation, because any
human being approached that way

is going to respond either
by attacking you, getting

defensive, deflecting,
denying, doubling down,
because that's only human.

Anybody trying to
public shame me,

I'm going to kick their
ass because that's
how we are trained to respond.

I'm not going to run
to the firing squad

and say, just shoot me
because I've been wrong.

I don't have that kind
of martyr complex.
And most of us don't.

The ultimate callout is
canceling somebody, though,

because not only do you want
to hold them accountable,

but you want to
get them real good.

So you want them
to lose their job,

or at least lose their
platform or their reputation.

And so canceling is
the ultimate expression

of the prison industrial
complex because you
want to invisiblize them.
You want to exile them.

You don't ever want them to be
heard from again because you've

attached what they've
done to the fact

that they don't deserve
to exist anymore socially.
Doesn't really work, though.

How many celebrities have you
actually seen get canceled?

And then there are some
politicians, like Trump,

who ride a cancelation impulse
all the way to the White House,

because shamelessness
is his currency,

besides a whole lot of other
narcissistic tendencies.

But he certainly has
legitimated shamelessness

as a political weapon
that has then now
infected the whole damn party.
The third one is calling in.

Calling in is not the opposite
of calling out, by the way.

People sometimes do
it in a binary way.

No, because it's also an
accountability process.

But instead of
using anger, blaming

and shaming as
your tactic, you're

going to choose to
use love and respect,

because when you call people
in, you don't call people
in because of who they are.

You call people in
because of who you are.

You are manifesting how you
want to be in relationship

with another person
and in relationship
to the struggle and the world.

It's a display of your own
integrity, so to speak.

And so a classic
calling in would be,

you know when you said
that at the staff meeting
the other day?

That was a perspective
I'm not used to.

Do you mind if we have
coffee and talk about it?

You still are calling
attention to the problem.

You're still saying, I'm not
comfortable letting this lay.

But at the same time,
you invited them

into a conversation
instead of a fight.
It's a choice that you have.

You have no obligation
to blow somebody's life

up just because you disagree
with something they said.

You have a choice about
whether you make the world more
cruel than it needs to be.

That is not honoring the
human rights framework,

when you are spreading
cruelty and calling it
radical activism.

The problem we have is that
we have a radical analysis,

but we don't have the
radical love practices

that people like
Audre Lorde taught

us to accompany this
radical analysis,

because we mistake critical
inquiry for criticism,

and can't tell the
difference between the two.
The fourth C is Calling On.

That's when you are requesting
that people do better,

but you're not at all interested
in investing your time
and attention into their growth.

It's the talk to
your hand strategy.

And sometimes, you just
ain't there for it.

And if you call them out or
call them in, both of those

require your time and
attention, and sometimes, you
ain't feeling that.
So it could take the form of--

well, my favorite is
that polite fiction
called "I beg your pardon?"
And then I just wait.

Because I ain't
begging shit, really.

I'm just not giving
them the response

that they expected from whatever
they said out of their mouths.

And another one
might be, "I'm not

quite sure what I'm doing
to make you think you could
say that kind of thing to me."
And then call them in or out.

You just turn the
lens on yourself

and say, what am I doing to
make you think you could give me

that sexist, homophobic,
transphobic, whatever, remark
and expect me to agree with you?

Whenever you use those kinds
of calling on responses,

you can see them
walking the words back
through their own head.

And they usually come at
you a totally different way,

because they didn't
get the response
that they were expecting.

What you're doing is calling on
is that you're inviting people

to reconcile that inner
good opinion of themselves

with their outer
behaviors, because usually,

the cognitive dissonance
is kicking their ass.

I mean, I've deprogrammed
white supremacists.

I've been in situations where
I've seen men standing there

in Klan robes, and
the first thing

they'll say to a Black person
is, but I'm not a racist.
Extreme cognitive dissonance.
Yeah?

But that's kind of how
we are, because we're

in a racially illiterate
society, so there's
a continuum.
There's degrees of that.

Our problem, I think,
as the human rights

movement, and particularly
as a Black person in it,

is that we do such
poor threat assessments

that we can't tell
the difference

between an actual enemy
and a problematic ally,

because they both
exhibit degrees of racism
and racial illiteracy.

And we tend to
conflate them all,

because we can't make a
difference between someone who

embraces white supremacy as
an ideology and someone who
has a white identity.
Those are not the same thing.

Because obviously, not all white
people are white supremacists.

And sadly, not all white
supremacists are white.
Clarence Thomas, anybody?
You know?

And so not being able to do
an accurate threat assessment

is also driving
call out culture,

because we have imprecise
definitions of harm.

We have all these
unverifiable claims of harm.

You just made you
feel threatened!

Just because somebody
disagreed with you?
That's not a verifiable claim.

And I'm supposed to take it
seriously just because you
said you've been hurt?

Frankly, I want to say get
the [MUTED] over yourself.

Because the purpose
of the human rights

movement is to end
oppression, not to serve
as your personal therapy space.

Get a therapist
instead of a keyboard
is what I so often want to say.

But I'm trying to
call myself in.
Whew.
[LAUGHTER]
So anyway.

And then the fifth
C is Calling It Off.

That's where you actively
seek to disengage

from an unproductive
conversation--

when people aren't
operating in good faith,

when they're
choosing to lie, when

they're trying to win at
all costs, switching sides,

gaslighting you,
all that other crap.

And whether it's in
person or online,

you have a choice about
how much time you're

going to invest in an
unproductive conversation

that's designed
to manipulate you.

I think we need to do
more calling it off,

because we mistakenly
think that if we continue

these protracted, unproductive
conversations, that we'll

eventually change
somebody's mind.

Which ain't true,
because none of us

have the power of
those magic words.

I mean, if we had the
magic words of change,
couples wouldn't fight.

The person you sleep with every
night wouldn't fight with you.
You know?
Friends wouldn't fight.
Colleagues wouldn't fight.
Nobody's got those magic words.

But our egos convince us
that if we could just info

dump on them, or find the
magic words, or whatever,
that they're just going to flip.
It doesn't happen like that.

The most you could
offer is your example.

But their epiphany has
to happen within them.
And you can't force it.

But you can model
it by how you choose

to invite people into a
conversational space instead
of a fight.

By the way, it may not work
the first 10 times you try it.

I know I've got a
really hard head.

You can tell me it's maybe not
till the 11th time I really

hear you, because that's
how human beings are.

And so having created
this analysis of the call

out culture, let's
talk about, well, what
do you do to call people in?

The first thing is
the self-assessment.

Make sure that you're
in a healed enough space

to build a container
for a conversation that
may make you uncomfortable.

Because if you're not in
that healed enough space,

if you're still bleeding
from your soul wounds,

all you're going to do is bleed
all over the other person.
That ain't going to help.

So it's not obligatory
that you call somebody in.
It has to be your choice.

Because you can
always call it off.
Talk to the hand.
Call it on.

There's a whole lot of things
from that buffet, that menu,
you can choose.

But if you have done
your self-assessment

and you think you're in a space
you need to call somebody out,

in, or on, then you
have to ask yourself,

am I in a space to give the
other person the benefit

of the doubt without assuming
that the words I'm reacting to

represents the totality
of their character?

I find that people
just use bad words,

or they use words badly, because
that's the racial, gender,

and all of those illteracies
I just talked about.

And so quite often, you have
to go underneath the words
and speak to their values.
You know?

Somebody might
say, I don't think

we should feed all those lazy
people on welfare, for example.

And so you could react
to that as most of us
progressives would, right there.

Or we could go
underneath their words

and say, OK, maybe we shouldn't
feed people on welfare.

But what do you think we should
do about hungry children?

Because they're not even
old enough to work yet?
You know?

Or I'll just say
maybe you believe
in feeding hungry children.

And as a human
rights activist, I

want to know why they're
hungry in the first place.

We're working on the same
issue, but in different ways.

Quite often, when you
speak to their values,

you're actually finding
the common ground

that allows you to have
quite different conversations

than you expected
if you just stay
on the surface of their words.

I teach this stuff
online, by the way.

So if you ever want to sign
up at LorettaJRoss.com.
Every lesson is $5.

I call myself the Walmart
of Consciousness Raising.
[LAUGHTER]

For the cost of a
cup of coffee, you
can learn calling in techniques.

And people are
telling me it works.

They're having interesting
and amazing conversations

with their mother in-laws that
they didn't think that they
could ever talk to, you know?

With the neighbor next door
that they've been fighting
over the Confederate flag.

I mean, they are just really
having amazing conversations

by not dehumanizing people
to what they see of them,

but really having authentic,
heartfelt conversations
with each other.

And so it also is important, if
you're going to use calling in,

to accept that
people are supposed
to have a variety of opinions.

That's the best way to
build a strong movement.

Because when many
different people think

many different thoughts and
they move in the same direction,

that's why it's
called a movement.

But when many different
people think one

thought and they move in the
same direction, that's a cult.

And we are not building
the human rights cult.

And the more time you put
trying to get everybody

to perfectly align with your
idea of what should be done,

and how right you are,
and blah, blah, blah,

you're bringing those
cult-like building practices

into what should be a diverse
human rights movement.

And I feel that a lot
of the call out culture

is driven by people trying
to do the right thing,

but they're going
about it the wrong way.

So these aren't
malevolent people.

These are not people
who want to destroy
the unity of the movement.

But they've been convinced
that the way to build power

is to build a cult so that they
can't tolerate disagreement,
even in a high-unity movement.

You know, we can
recognize each other

when we say
neoliberal capitalism,
and heteropatriarchy, and stuff.

But they were still
trying to say,

but you have to use this
word the way I use it.

You have to think
this thought the way

I think it should
be thought, and you

should use this strategy the
way I think you should use it.

I mean, we still do all of that
calling out amongst each other,

as if that's the
way you build power.

You know, you build
power with the people

who most agree with
you, with the people who

agree with you 75% of the
time, with the people who agree
with you 50% of the time--

you build power amongst
all those people.

And they're OK staying
where they are.
So I got the time up.

So thank you all
for listening to me,

and I hope we continue this
conversation about building
a calling in culture.
[APPLAUSE]
